"This year's rushing season was
of the best we have ever had,"

this week. "And taken on the
whole, it was one of the cleanest."
According to Veverka, there
were quite a few violations of the
rushing rules reported this year,
but except for one, they were
minor in nature.
Most of these violations involved
misunderstandings of the rushing
rules by freshmen or fraternities.

A program to assist outstanding

at Los Angeles or the University

will work full time during the
summer in the Hughes Laboratories
and 25 hours per week while pursuing a half-time schedule of
graduate study at the university.
Salary is commensurate with the
individual's ability and experience.
Tuition, admission fees and books
for university attendance are provided. Provision is made to assist in
paying travel and moving expenses
from outside Southern California.

HOW TO APPLY

Eligible for these Fellowships are
those who have completed one year
of graduate study in physics or
engineering. Successful candidates
must qualify for graduate standing
at the California Institute of Technology for study toward the degree
of Doctor of Philosophy or postdoctoral work. Fellows may pursue
graduate research in the fields of
physics or engineering. During
summers they will work full time
in the Hughes laboratories in
association with scientists and engineers in their fields.
Each appointment is for twelve
months and provides a cash award
of not less than $2,000, a salary of
not less than $2,5ou. and $i,soo for
tuition and research expenses. A
suitable adjustment is made When
financial responsibilities of the Fellow might otherwise preclude participation in the program. For those
coming from outside the Southern
California area provision is made
for moving and transportation

SC prexy of the caliber we called for last April, it is perhaps
too early in the year to say.

He has made several statements redefining the Council's
position on campus and that of the entire undergraduate student
body. With some phases of his re-definition, especially his, what
seems to us, undue emphasis on "rah-rah" collegiate spirit we
disagree.
But he has been the man to motivate the Council to revise
its vague, archaic constitution (see p. 1). What's more he has
decided to tackle the revision of the SC constitution first before
proceeding to a review of the constitutions of other organizations.
(This is a marked and laudable contrast to previous Council administrations which have tended to "revise" all other constitutions
but blatantly ignored their own sad one.)
However, in la.st April's editorial we also stated that one
particularly vague clause in the SC constitution "as it stands ...
tends to give the impression that the Council and the student body
presume upon themselyes the powers of the University administration." Unfortunately, after sitting in on all but one of the
Council's meetings this year, and hearing Phinney talk, it seems at
times that he has presumed upon himself not only just pie preroga—
tives of the University administration, but also those of almost
everybody else including the good Lord himself.
When revising their constitution, we hope the Council attains
a firmer grasp upon reality than they have hitherto displayed.
We hope that they will always keep in mind the fact that they arc
the student body's representatives, and that the Student Council
is a part of tlie Hopkips, not the Hopkins a iart of the Council.

W. D. Garland, E.E. '52, Univ. of
California, is working for the Pacific
Telephone Company. We thought
you'd be inteirested in what Don
told, us about his first assignment.
(Reading time:,45 seconds)
Here Don Garland makes noise distribution measurements
with a Level Distribution Recorder

•
My job is to help solve problems
of noise and other interference on telephone lines due to power interference.
Inductive co-ordination is the technical
term for the work.
"First thing the Chief Engineer explained to me was that 'all the answers
aren't in the book.' He was right. Most
of the problems"have required a combination of electrical engineering, a
knowledge of costs and generous
amount of ingenuity. I like it that way.
It's given me an immediate opportunity
to put into practice the theory I learned
at school.

"In addition to this on-the-job experience, I have attended several special training courses conducted by the
company. Now I'm breaking in a new
man, just like when I started."

Loss To Terrors Closes
Sad JHU Grid Campaign
Closing out the season with a
loss in the mire of the Western
Maryland field to the Green
Terrors, 12-7, Hopkins' Blue Jays
hung up their equipment and
Head Coach John Bridgers began
the task of wrapping up the season and beginning plans for next
year.
Standing in the empty dressing
room amid the ringlets of mud
formed by cleats; the empty hangers which had borne the burden
of shoulder pads, helmets, and
shoes; and the scouting sheets on
Western Maryland on the floor,
Bridgers took time out from the
task of cleaning up to give his
summary of the season.
"It was a disappointirig season," said Bridgers,' from the
standpoint of the players, coaches,
and students. Actually, I think a
true appraisal of our team in

SC prexy of the caliber we called for last April, it is perhaps
too early in the year to say.

He has made several statements redefining the Council's
position on campus and that of the entire undergraduate student
body. With some phases of his re-definition, especially his, what
seems to us, undue emphasis on "rah-rah" collegiate spirit we
disagree.
But he has been the man to motivate the Council to revise
its vague, archaic constitution (see p. 1). What's more he has
decided to tackle the revision of the SC constitution first before
proceeding to a review of the constitutions of other organizations.
(This is a marked and laudable contrast to previous Council administrations which have tended to "revise" all other constitutions
but blatantly ignored their own sad one.)
However, in la.st April's editorial we also stated that one
particularly vague clause in the SC constitution "as it stands ...
tends to give the impression that the Council and the student body
presume upon themselyes the powers of the University administration." Unfortunately, after sitting in on all but one of the
Council's meetings this year, and hearing Phinney talk, it seems at
times that he has presumed upon himself not only just pie preroga—
tives of the University administration, but also those of almost
everybody else including the good Lord himself.
When revising their constitution, we hope the Council attains
a firmer grasp upon reality than they have hitherto displayed.
We hope that they will always keep in mind the fact that they arc
the student body's representatives, and that the Student Council
is a part of tlie Hopkips, not the Hopkins a iart of the Council.

W. D. Garland, E.E. '52, Univ. of
California, is working for the Pacific
Telephone Company. We thought
you'd be inteirested in what Don
told, us about his first assignment.
(Reading time:,45 seconds)
Here Don Garland makes noise distribution measurements
with a Level Distribution Recorder

•
My job is to help solve problems
of noise and other interference on telephone lines due to power interference.
Inductive co-ordination is the technical
term for the work.
"First thing the Chief Engineer explained to me was that 'all the answers
aren't in the book.' He was right. Most
of the problems"have required a combination of electrical engineering, a
knowledge of costs and generous
amount of ingenuity. I like it that way.
It's given me an immediate opportunity
to put into practice the theory I learned
at school.

"In addition to this on-the-job experience, I have attended several special training courses conducted by the
company. Now I'm breaking in a new
man, just like when I started."

Loss To Terrors Closes
Sad JHU Grid Campaign
Closing out the season with a
loss in the mire of the Western
Maryland field to the Green
Terrors, 12-7, Hopkins' Blue Jays
hung up their equipment and
Head Coach John Bridgers began
the task of wrapping up the season and beginning plans for next
year.
Standing in the empty dressing
room amid the ringlets of mud
formed by cleats; the empty hangers which had borne the burden
of shoulder pads, helmets, and
shoes; and the scouting sheets on
Western Maryland on the floor,
Bridgers took time out from the
task of cleaning up to give his
summary of the season.
"It was a disappointirig season," said Bridgers,' from the
standpoint of the players, coaches,
and students. Actually, I think a
true appraisal of our team in
comparison with the teams that
we played is that we shouldn't
have expected to be much better.
But I felt that we never really got
the maximum out of ourselves.
There never seemed to be a game
In which were able to put togther our best passing, running,
blocking, and defense."
Luck.At Record
The record bears out the fact
that the season was disappointing.
Hopkins won but two contests
while dropping six. The season
ended as it started, with a loss—
the opening game to Franklin and
Marshall, 41-19, the final tilt to
Western Maryland, 12-7. In between were sandwiched losses to
